name: Scope
comment: angular-core.Scope is represents a collection of angular-core.Scope.watches observeers, and angular-core.Scope.context for the watchers, observers and angular-core.Scope.evaluations. Scopes structure loosely mimics the DOM structure. Scopes and Views are bound to each other. As scopes are created and destroyed by ViewFactory they are responsible for change detection, change processing and memory management.

context.name: context
context.comment: The default execution context for angular-core.RootScope.watches observeers, and angular-core.RootScope.evaluation.

hasOwnStreams.name: hasOwnStreams
hasOwnStreams.comment: Do not use. Exposes internal state for testing.

isAttached.name: isAttached
isAttached.comment: Returns true if the scope is still attached to the angular-core.RootScope.

isDestroyed.name: isDestroyed
isDestroyed.comment: Return true if the scope has been destroyed. Once scope is destroyed No operations are allowed on it.

watch.name: watch
watch.comment:
Use angular-core.Scope.watch to set up change detection on an expression.

  • angular-core.Scope.watch.expression: The expression to watch for changes.

  • angular-core.Scope.watch.reactionFn: The reaction function to execute when a change is detected in the watched expression.

  • angular-core.Scope.watch.context: The object against which the expression is evaluated. This defaults to the angular-core.Scope.context if no context is specified.

  • angular-core.Scope.watch.formatters: If the watched expression contains formatters, this map specifies the set of formatters that are used by the expression.

  • angular-core.Scope.watch.canChangeModel: Specifies whether the angular-core.Scope.watch.reactionFn changes the model. Reaction functions that change the model are processed as part of the digest cycle. Otherwise, they are processed as part of the flush cycle.

  • angular-core.Scope.watch.collection: If true, then the expression points to a collection (a list or a map), and the collection should be shallow watched. If false then the expression is watched by reference. When watching a collection, the reaction function receives a change_detection.CollectionChangeItem that lists all the changes.

hashCode.name: hashCode
hashCode.comment:
Get a hash code for this object.

All objects have hash codes. Hash codes are guaranteed to be the same for objects that are equal when compared using the equality operator ==. Other than that there are no guarantees about the hash codes. They will not be consistent between runs and there are no distribution guarantees.

If a subclass overrides angular-core.Scope.hashCode it should override the equality operator as well to maintain consistency.

runtimeType.name: runtimeType
runtimeType.comment: A representation of the runtime type of the object.

==.comment:
The equality operator.

The default behavior for all dart-core.Objects is to return true if and only if this and angular-core.Scope.==.other are the same object.

Override this method to specify a different equality relation on a class. The overriding method must still be an equivalence relation. That is, it must be:

  • Total: It must return a boolean for all arguments. It should never throw or return null.

  • Reflexive: For all objects o, o == o must be true.

  • Symmetric: For all objects o1 and o2, o1 == o2 and o2 == o1 must either both be true, or both be false.

  • Transitive: For all objects o1, o2, and o3, if o1 == o2 and o2 == o3 are true, then o1 == o3 must be true.

The method should also be consistent over time, so equality of two objects should not change over time, or at least only change if one of the objects was modified.

If a subclass overrides the equality operator it should override the angular-core.Scope.hashCode method as well to maintain consistency.

noSuchMethod.name: noSuchMethod
noSuchMethod.comment:
angular-core.Scope.noSuchMethod is invoked when users invoke a non-existent method on an object. The name of the method and the arguments of the invocation are passed to angular-core.Scope.noSuchMethod in an dart-core.Invocation. If angular-core.Scope.noSuchMethod returns a value, that value becomes the result of the original invocation.

The default behavior of angular-core.Scope.noSuchMethod is to throw a dart-core.NoSuchMethodError.

toString.name: toString
toString.comment: Returns a string representation of this object.
